article:
The American Petroleum Institute gravity, or 'API gravity', is a measure of how
heavy or light a petroleum liquid is compared to water. If its API gravity is
greater than 10, it is lighter and floats on water; if less than 10, it is
heavier and sinks. API gravity is thus an inverse measure of the relative
density of a petroleum liquid and the density of water, but it is used to
compare the relative densities of petroleum liquids. For example, if one
petroleum liquid floats on another and is therefore less dense, it has a greater
API gravity. Although mathematically, API gravity has no units (see the formula
below), it is nevertheless referred to as being in "degrees". API gravity is
gradated in degrees on a hydrometer instrument. The API scale was designed so
that most values would fall between 10 and 70 API gravity degrees.
